pr_title: feat: Correct Kubernetes labels and labels refactor

timeline.message:
feat: Correct Kubernetes labels and labels refactor

- Modify the app.kubernetes.io/name label to reflect the
correct apps for each component
These labels are queryable so that a user can see all 'kafka',
'zookeeper' etc components in a cluster
- Modify the app.kubernetes.io/part-of label to have a unique
identifier for each instance of a cluster
This is mostly for the openshift Ui which clusters applications
based on their part-of label
- Refactored labels so that all models build up their labels
in a similar fashion.
Made explicit the subset of labels that constitute a strimzi  selector
label this should assist in  avoiding breaking bugs in future

Signed-off-by: Samuel Hawker <samuel.hawker@ibm.com>ase enter the commit message for your changes. Lines starting

We do need it, but I have moved the merge to arguably the correct place to put it, in each model when the labels are initially defined, I think merging the labels this late is an anti-pattern and causes more confusion.

replies.bodyText:
So I had a long time thinking about this. Originally I didn't include it as I did not want to add a HasMetadata as an argument, but also it sort of made sense to me that since all other label set fields are defined outside of the constructor this one should be also...
Happy to move it in if you disagree with this approach
replies.author: samuel-hawker

replies.bodyText: I can probably live with this if you think it is better. I there is a risk that one day someone will forget to add it to some new model. However, as for adding the HasMetadatato the constructor ... it seesm in most cases you call it anyway with something like this as parameters: kafkaAssembly.getMetadata().getNamespace(), kafkaAssembly.getMetadata().getName(). So maybe the constructor could have only HasMetadata and get the name, namespace and labels out of it on its own.

replies.bodyText: Another option would be to define an abstract getter in AbstractModel, forcing subclasses to override it. I actually think this is preferable, since there's no need for this property to be mutable AFAICT.
